ground_truth: He suddenly notices a herd of cattle grazing at the roadside and murmurs. He swings the tommy gun over with a whoop. One of the cows drops and the rest stampede toward the road. Energized, Nelson resumes bellowing. In bovine ignorance of the conventions of high-speed police pursuit, some of the cows have wandered up onto the road. The lead police car broadsides one. George Nelson, cackling wildly, fires into the air as his car recedes. The car is speeding into town, dodging and weaving through light traffic as George fires into the air - perhaps a means of clearing a path, perhaps an expression of high spirits. The car screeches to a halt and George hops out, and the three convicts emerge to follow him. Jowls shaking in a full run, George Nelson bursts through the door of the bank, followed by the three men. He fires into the ceiling and leaps up onto a table. He leaps down, fires into the air again, and sweeps a young woman standing in line into a full V-J dip, kissing her on the lips. Delmar nudges Everett. He whips open his suitcoat to reveal a half-dozen sticks of dynamite. He sends a burst into the ceiling, and heads for the door as customers murmur. George whirls. The customers stare mutely back. The customers shuffle their feet and glance uncomfortably about. Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder and tries to steer him toward the door. George responds, barely audible and without brightening. Everett and Pete exchange significant looks. He digs into a pocket and tosses his car keys to a dumbfounded Delmar. George has turned woodenly and walks away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light. Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money. A stakebed truck approaches along the road bordering the field. It is festooned with Stokes banners showing the candidate holding high a broom. Pickers perform in the bed of the truck, along with a dancer doing a two-step as he pushes a broom. A midget in overalls waves his arms, as if conducting the music. He switches off the microphone as the song, a duet of 'I'll Fly Away', scratchily issues from a monitor. He turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. The three men walk down a flat delta road, the sun shimmering off the rough pavement. The three men stand in the middle distance, waiting. In the foreground two little black boys are walking home, each carrying a block of ice. A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable. The crude black label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: He abruptly observes a group of cattle grazing at the roadside and mutters. He swings the submachine gun over with a shout. One of the cows falls and the remainder stampede toward the road. Energized, Nelson continues yelling. In bovine ignorance of the conventions of high-speed law enforcement pursuit, some of the cows have wandered up onto the road. The lead police car broadsides one. George Nelson, laughing wildly, shoots into the air as his car recedes. The car is speeding into town, dodging and weaving through light traffic as George shoots into the air—perhaps a means of clearing a path, perhaps an expression of high spirits. The car screeches to a halt and George jumps out, and the three convicts emerge to follow him. Jowls shaking in a full run, George Nelson bursts through the door of the bank, followed by the three men. He shoots into the ceiling and leaps up onto a table. He leaps down, shoots into the air again, and sweeps a young woman standing in line into a full V-J dip, kissing her on the lips. Delmar nudges Everett. He whips open his suitcoat to reveal a half-dozen sticks of dynamite. He sends a burst into the ceiling, and heads for the door as customers mutter. George spins. The customers stare mutely back. The customers shuffle their feet and glance uncomfortably about. Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder and tries to steer him toward the door. George responds, barely audible and without brightening. Everett and Pete exchange meaningful looks. He digs into a pocket and tosses his car keys to a dumbstruck Delmar. George has turned woodenly and walks away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light. Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money. A stakebed truck approaches along the road bordering the field. It is adorned with Stokes banners showing the candidate holding high a broom. Pickers perform in the bed of the truck, along with a dancer doing a two-step as he pushes a broom. A midget in overalls waves his arms, as if conducting the music. He switches off the microphone as the song, a duet of 'I'll Fly Away', scratchily issues from a speaker. He turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. The three men walk down a flat delta road, the sun shimmering off the rough pavement. The three men stand in the middle distance, waiting. In the foreground two little black boys are walking home, each carrying a block of ice. A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable. The crude black label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: He suddenly notices a herd of cattle grazing at the roadside, and a murmur is made by him. The tommy gun is swung over with a whoop by him. One of the cows is dropped, and the rest stampede toward the road. Energized, bellowing is resumed by Nelson. In bovine ignorance of the conventions of high-speed police pursuit, some of the cows wander up onto the road. The lead police car broadside one. Cackling wildly, George Nelson fires into the air as their car recedes. The car speeds into town, dodging and weaving through light traffic as George fires into the air—perhaps as a means of clearing a path, perhaps as an expression of high spirits. A halt is screeched to by the car, and George hops out; he is followed by the three convicts who emerge. Jowls shaking in a full run, the door of the bank is burst through by George Nelson, followed by the three men. The ceiling is fired into by him, and he leaps up onto a table. He leaps down, fires into the air again, and a young woman standing in line is swept into a full V-J dip by him, kissed on the lips. Everett is nudged by Delmar. A half-dozen sticks of dynamite are revealed when he whips open his suitcoat. A burst is sent into the ceiling, and the door is headed for by him as customers murmur. George whirls. The customers stare mutely back. Their feet are shuffled by the customers, and they glance uncomfortably about. A hand is laid on George's shoulder by Delmar, and he tries to steer him toward the door. George barely audibly responds without brightening. Significant looks are exchanged by Everett and Pete. A pocket is dug into by him, and his car keys are tossed to a dumbfounded Delmar. George has turned woodenly and walks away, leaving the flickering circle of light from the campfire. Everett is stared at by Delmar, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. The loose money is scrambled to be picked up by Pete. Along the road bordering the field approaches a stakebed truck. Stokes banners festoon it, showing the candidate holding high a broom. In the bed of the truck, a dancer performs a two-step while pushing a broom as pickers perform. A midget in overalls waves his arms, conducting the music. The microphone is switched off by him as a duet of 'I'll Fly Away' comes scratchily from a monitor. His attention is turned back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. Down a flat delta road, the sun shimmering off the rough pavement, walk the three men. In the middle distance, the three men stand, waiting. In the foreground, two little black boys walk home, each carrying a block of ice. A green felt turntable spins a 78. It is identified crudely by the black label as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He spots a herd of cattle grazing by the roadside and murmurs. Swiveling the tommy gun with a whoop, he drops one cow, prompting the rest to stampede onto the road. Nelson, energized, resumes bellowing. Ignorant of police chase conventions, some cows wander onto the road, one of which the lead police car broadsides. George Nelson, cackling wildly, fires into the air as his car speeds into town, dodging light traffic, perhaps to clear a path or express high spirits. The car screeches to a halt, and he and three convicts jump out. Jowls shaking, George bursts into the bank, followed by the men, fires at the ceiling, leaps onto a table, then down, and dips a woman in a full V-J dip, kissing her. Delmar nudges Everett, revealing dynamite. He bursts into the ceiling and heads for the door as customers murmur. George turns, customers stare mutely, shuffling uncomfortably. Delmar tries steering George out; George responds barely audible. Everett and Pete exchange looks. George tosses his car keys to Delmar, who stares as George woodenly walks away from the campfire's flickering light. Pete collects money. A stakebed truck with Stokes banners approaches, pickers perform on it, and a dancer does a two-step. A midget in overalls conducts the music and switches off the microphone as 'I'll Fly Away' ends. He turns back to a well-dressed man nearby. The three men walk a delta road shimmering under the sun, waiting. In the foreground, two young black boys carry blocks of ice home. A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable identifies itself as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Noticing a herd of cattle at the roadside, Nelson murmurs and swings the tommy gun. A cow drops, and the rest stampede. Ignorant of police pursuit, cows wander onto the road, and the lead police car hits one. Nelson cackles and fires into the air as his car speeds into town, dodging traffic. It stops, and Nelson, with three convicts, bursts into a bank, firing into the ceiling. He kisses a woman, then Delmar reveals dynamite, prompting murmurs. Customers stare uncomfortably. Delmar steers George out, who woodenly leaves, tossing car keys to Delmar. Everett appraises George as Pete gathers money. A stakebed truck with Stokes banners and performers approaches. A midget conducts music, switches off the microphone, and turns to a well-dressed man. The three men walk a delta road, sun shimmering. They stand waiting as two boys carry ice, and a spinning record plays 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He suddenly becomes aware of a sizable herd of cattle peacefully grazing right by the side of the road and murmurs to himself. With a loud whoop of excitement, he swings the tommy gun around. As a result, one of the unsuspecting cows drops, while the rest of the herd frantically stampede toward the road in a chaotic frenzy. Energized and invigorated by the commotion, Nelson resumes his bellowing. In their bovine ignorance of the norms and conventions of a high-speed police pursuit, some of the cows have already wandered up onto the road. The lead police car collides sideways with one of them. Amused and cackling wildly, George Nelson fires into the air as his getaway car recedes into the distance. The car, speeding toward town, continues to dodge and weave through the light traffic, with George firing into the sky—perhaps as a means to clear a path or perhaps simply as an expression of his high spirits. The car screeches to a sudden halt and George energetically hops out, followed promptly by the three convicts who emerge to accompany him. With jowls shaking as he runs at full speed, George Nelson bursts through the bank's door, followed closely by the trio of men. Firing into the ceiling, he leaps up onto a table with enthusiasm. He then leaps down, again firing into the air, and sweeps a young woman who is standing in line into an elaborate full V-J dip, planting a kiss on her lips. Delmar nudges Everett, hinting at something. He dramatically whips open his suitcoat to reveal an ominous half-dozen sticks of dynamite. He sends another burst into the ceiling and heads toward the door as the customers start to murmur anxiously. George whirls around to face them. The customers stare back at him, mute and wide-eyed. They shuffle their feet and glance about uncomfortably, with a mounting sense of unease. Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder, trying to steer him toward the door with gentle insistence. George responds, barely audible, without showing any sign of brightening. Everett and Pete exchange significant looks, filled with understanding. George digs into a pocket and tosses his car keys to a dumbfounded Delmar. Having turned woodenly, George walks away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light behind him. Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Meanwhile, Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money scattered about. A stakebed truck approaches along the road that borders the field. It is festooned with Stokes banners displaying the candidate triumphantly holding high a broom. Pickers perform lively music in the bed of the truck, accompanied by a dancer energetically doing a two-step as he pushes a broom. A midget in overalls enthusiastically waves his arms, as if he is conducting the music. He switches off the microphone just as the song, a scratchy duet of 'I'll Fly Away,' issues forth from a nearby monitor. He then turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. The three men walk down a flat delta road, the sun shimmering off the rough pavement beneath their feet. The three men stand in the middle distance, waiting patiently. In the foreground, two little black boys are walking home, each carrying a carefully balanced block of ice. A spinning 78 is on a green felt turntable. The crude black label on the record identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Suddenly, he becomes acutely conscious of a quite sizable herd of cattle that are peacefully grazing right by the side of the road. Mumbling to himself, a loud whoop of excitement escapes him as he eagerly swings the tommy gun around in an animated motion. As a direct consequence of his actions, one of the unsuspecting cows abruptly drops to the ground, while the rest of the herd bursts into a frantic stampede, racing toward the road in a chaotic frenzy. With a surge of energy and invigoration fueled by the commotion, Nelson resumes his bellowing with zeal and vigor. In their bovine ignorance of the norms and conventions associated with a high-speed police pursuit, a few of the cows have already managed to wander up onto the roadway. The lead police car unavoidably collides sideways with one of them. Amused beyond measure and cackling wildly, George Nelson fires his gun into the air as his getaway car recedes into the distance at an incredible speed. The car, speeding with urgency toward town, continues to dodge and weave through the light traffic, with George persistently firing into the sky—perhaps in an attempt to clear a path or perhaps simply as an expression of his exuberant high spirits. The car eventually screeches to a sudden halt, and George energetically hops out, followed promptly by the trio of convicts who emerge to accompany him. With his jowls shaking animatedly as he runs at full speed, George Nelson bursts through the bank's door, trailing closely behind by the three men. Firing enthusiastically into the ceiling, he leaps up onto a table, brimming with enthusiasm. He then leaps down once more, again firing into the air, and sweeps a young woman who is standing in line into an elaborate full V-J dip, planting a kiss on her lips with theatrical flourish. Delmar nudges Everett, hinting at something with a knowing expression. He dramatically whips open his suitcoat to reveal an ominous half-dozen sticks of dynamite. Sending another burst into the ceiling, he strides toward the door as the customers start to murmur anxiously, a growing sense of unease permeating the air. George whirls around to face them directly. The customers stare back at him, their expressions mute and wide-eyed, shuffling their feet and glancing about uncomfortably, sensing the mounting tension in the atmosphere. Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder, attempting to steer him toward the door with gentle insistence. George responds quietly, barely audible, and without showing any sign of brightening. Everett and Pete exchange significant looks, filled with understanding and silent communication. George digs into his pocket and nonchalantly tosses his car keys to a dumbfounded Delmar. Having turned woodenly, George walks away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light behind him. Delmar stares intently at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Meanwhile, Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money scattered about. A stakebed truck approaches along the road that borders the field. It is festooned with colorful Stokes banners, displaying the candidate triumphantly holding high a broom. Pickers perform lively music in the bed of the truck, accompanied by a dancer energetically doing a spirited two-step as he pushes a broom. A midget in overalls waves his arms with enthusiasm, as if he is conducting the lively music. He switches off the microphone just as the song, a scratchy duet of 'I'll Fly Away,' issues forth from a nearby monitor. He then turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. The three men walk steadily down a flat delta road, the sun shimmering off the rough pavement beneath their feet. The three men stand patiently in the middle distance, waiting with calm demeanor. In the foreground, two little black boys are depicted walking home, each carefully balancing a block of ice with precision. A spinning 78 rests on a green felt turntable, and the crude black label on the record identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As he gazes out, his eyes suddenly catch sight of a herd of cattle grazing peacefully at the roadside, prompting him to murmur softly under his breath. In a spontaneous burst of energy, he swings the tommy gun over his shoulder with a jubilant whoop and takes aim, leading to a startling moment when one of the cows collapses, sending the rest of the herd stampeding toward the road in a frenzy. This surge of energy invigorates Nelson, who resumes his boisterous bellowing. Oblivious to the rules and dangers of a high-speed police chase, some of the cows have meandered onto the road, presenting an unfortunate obstacle. The lead police car, unable to avoid the obstruction, collides with one of the animals, skidding sideways upon impact. Meanwhile, George Nelson is overtaken by a wild exhilaration, cackling loudly as he fires his gun into the air while his vehicle speeds away, weaving through sparse traffic in the direction of the town. The succession of shots might serve to clear the path ahead or simply express his high-spirited defiance. As the car screeches to a halt, he swiftly hops out, followed by the three convicts accompanying him. George, with his jowls shaking as he breaks into a full sprint, barrels through the bank's entrance with the men close behind. Inside, his presence is announced by the sharp crack of a gunshot into the ceiling, drawing all attention as he energetically leaps onto a table. Without missing a beat, he leaps down again, fires into the air once more for effect, and with brazen audacity, sweeps a young woman in line into a classic V-J dip, planting a kiss on her lips. Nearby, Delmar watches the spectacle unfold and nudges Everett, signaling a moment of shared disbelief. To further complicate matters, Delmar dramatically flings open his suitcoat to reveal an array of dynamite sticks strapped inside. As if to punctuate the commotion, he sends another shot into the ceiling before making his way to the exit, while the customers stand by, murmuring uncertainly. George, in his momentum, spins around, finding himself locked in an unspoken exchange with the customers who, in their speechless state, shuffle uneasily. In this charged moment, Delmar places a guiding hand on George's shoulder in an attempt to steer him toward the exit, though George's response is muted, barely audible, and void of his earlier enthusiasm. As Everett and Pete exchange meaningful glances, deliberating their next move, George digs into his pocket and, without a word, tosses his car keys to a bewildered Delmar. In a somber turn, George woodenly steps away, disappearing beyond the campfire's flickering glow, his retreating figure watched appraisingly by Everett. Pete, not missing an opportunity, swiftly gathers up the scattered money. Meanwhile, the scene shifts to a stakebed truck making its way along the road adjacent to the field, adorned with Stokes campaign banners depicting the candidate triumphantly wielding a broom. A lively performance unfolds in the truck's bed, featuring pickers and a dancer energetically two-stepping while handling a broom. Amidst this display, a midget attired in overalls waves his arms theatrically, as if leading the musical ensemble. He switches off the microphone, allowing the scratchy strains of 'I'll Fly Away' to drift from a nearby monitor. His focus soon shifts back to a well-dressed man seated close by. The three men venture down a flat delta road, the sun's rays glinting off the coarse pavement as they proceed. In the middle distance, they stand expectantly, maintaining a watchful stance while in the foreground, two young black boys trek home, each balancing a block of ice. Meanwhile, a spinning 78 record on a green felt turntable intermittently captures attention, its simple black label identifying it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Noticing a herd of cattle grazing by the roadside, George Nelson excitedly swings his tommy gun and fires, causing the cows to stampede onto the road. As the lead police car hits one, Nelson, filled with high spirits, continues firing into the air while speeding into town, deftly maneuvering through light traffic. The car screeches to a halt, and George, along with the three convicts, charges into a bank. Inside, George theatrically fires into the ceiling, leaps onto a table, then back down, and kisses a young woman in line. As Delmar reveals sticks of dynamite, the customers murmur uneasily, prompting Delmar to guide George toward the exit. George, somberly, hands his car keys to a stunned Delmar and walks away. Everett and Pete exchange looks, with Pete hastily collecting fallen money. Meanwhile, a stakebed truck adorned with Stokes banners approaches, featuring performers and a midget conducting music. As 'I'll Fly Away' plays over a monitor, the three men walk along a delta road, the sun glinting off the pavement, and they pause while two boys pass by carrying blocks of ice. Nearby, a spinning record on a turntable identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He suddenly notices a herd of cattle, domesticated animals often raised for meat or milk production, grazing at the roadside and murmurs. He swings the tommy gun, a submachine gun popularized by gangsters during the Prohibition era in the United States, over with a whoop. One of the cows drops as a result, causing the rest to stampede toward the road. Energized by the chaos, Nelson, known for his infamous criminal exploits, resumes bellowing. In bovine ignorance of the conventions of high-speed police pursuit, some of the cows have wandered up onto the road. The lead police car, a model commonly used by law enforcement in the 1930s, broadsides one. George Nelson, an infamous bank robber during the Great Depression, cackling wildly, fires into the air as his car recedes. The car is speeding into town, a small rural settlement typical of the era, dodging and weaving through light traffic as George fires into the air - perhaps a means of clearing a path, perhaps an expression of high spirits. The car screeches to a halt and George hops out, and the three convicts, fellow members of his notorious gang, emerge to follow him. Jowls shaking in a full run, George Nelson bursts through the door of the bank, an institution central to many rural communities despite the economic hardships, followed by the three men. He fires into the ceiling and leaps up onto a table. He leaps down, fires into the air again, and sweeps a young woman standing in line into a full V-J dip, a dance move popularized after World War II, kissing her on the lips. Delmar nudges Everett. He whips open his suitcoat to reveal a half-dozen sticks of dynamite, a favored tool for bank robbers seeking to intimidate or force entry. He sends a burst into the ceiling, creating a scene of panic, and heads for the door as customers murmur. George whirls. The customers, caught between fear and disbelief, stare mutely back. The customers shuffle their feet and glance uncomfortably about. Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder and tries to steer him toward the door. George responds, barely audible and without brightening. Everett and Pete exchange significant looks, perhaps reflecting the unspoken tensions within their criminal pursuits. He digs into a pocket and tosses his car keys, a prized possession during the economic struggles of the time, to a dumbfounded Delmar. George has turned woodenly and walks away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light, a fleeting moment of warmth and camaraderie. Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money, the ultimate goal of their desperate actions. A stakebed truck approaches along the road bordering the field. It is festooned with Stokes banners, representing a political campaign perhaps promising change, showing the candidate holding high a broom, symbolizing a clean sweep or new beginnings. Pickers perform in the bed of the truck, along with a dancer doing a two-step, a dance rooted in American folk traditions, as he pushes a broom. A midget in overalls waves his arms, as if conducting the music, adding to the atmosphere of rural celebration. He switches off the microphone as the song, a duet of 'I'll Fly Away', a hymn often associated with hope and afterlife, scratchily issues from a monitor. He turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby, likely an important figure in the campaign. The three men walk down a flat delta road, the sun shimmering off the rough pavement, typical of the southern landscape. The three men stand in the middle distance, waiting. In the foreground, two little black boys are walking home, illustrating the era's racial dynamics, each carrying a block of ice, a necessity before the widespread use of refrigerators. A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable plays. The crude black label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys, a fictional band featured in stories capturing the struggles and music of the time.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: He suddenly notices a herd of cattle grazing at the roadside and murmurs. He swings the tommy gun over with a whoop. One of the cows drops and the rest stampede toward the road. Energized Nelson resumes bellowing. In bovine ignorance of the conventions of highspeed police pursuit. some of the cows have wandered up onto the road. The lead police car broadsides one. George Nelson cackling wildly fires into the air as his car recedes. The car is speeding into town dodging and weaving through light traffic as George fires into the air. perhaps a means of clearing a path perhaps an expression of high spirits. The car screeches to a halt and George hops out and the three convicts emerge to follow him. Jowls shaking in a full run. George Nelson bursts through the door of the bank followed by the three men. He fires into the ceiling and leaps up onto a table. He leaps down fires into the air again and sweeps a young woman standing in line into a full VJ dip kissing her on the lips. Delmar nudges Everett. He whips open his suitcoat to reveal a halfdozen sticks of dynamite. He sends a burst into the ceiling and heads for the door as customers murmur. George whirls. The customers stare mutely back. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. The customers shuffle their feet and glance uncomfortably about. Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder and tries to steer him toward the door. George responds barely audible and without brightening. Everett and Pete exchange significant looks. He digs into a pocket and tosses his car keys to a dumbfounded Delmar. George has turned woodenly and walks away leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light. Delmar stares at Everett who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money. A stakebed truck approaches along the road bordering the field. It is festooned with Stokes banners showing the candidate holding high a broom. Pickers perform in the bed of the truck along with a dancer doing a twostep as he pushes a broom. A midget in overalls waves his arms as if conducting the music. He switches off the microphone as the song. a duet of 'I will Fly Away' scratchily issues from a monitor. He turns his attention back to a welldressed man sitting nearby. The three men walk down a flat delta road. the sun shimmering off the rough pavement. The three men stand in the middle distance waiting. In the foreground two little black boys are walking home each carrying a block of ice. A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable. The crude black label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

One of the birds falls and the rest soar toward the beach. Energized, Nelson resumes bellowing. In avian ignorance of the conventions of high-speed police pursuit, some of the seagulls have wandered up onto the sand. The lead police boat sideswipes one. George Nelson, cackling wildly, fires into the sky as his boat recedes. The boat is speeding into the harbor, dodging and weaving through light boats as George fires into the sky - perhaps a means of clearing a path, perhaps an expression of high spirits. The boat screeches to a halt and George hops out, and the three convicts emerge to follow him. Jowls shaking in a full run, George Nelson bursts through the door of the candy shop, followed by the three men. He fires into the ceiling and leaps up onto a countertop. George responds, barely audible and without brightening. Everett and Pete exchange significant looks. He digs into a pocket and tosses his boat keys to a dumbfounded Delmar. George has turned woodenly and walks away, leaving the fireplace's flickering circle of light. Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back. Musicians perform in the back of the van, along with a dancer doing a quickstep as he waves a fan. A child in overalls waves his arms, as if conducting the music. He switches off the radio as the song, a duet of 'I'll Fly Away', scratchily issues from a loudspeaker. He turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. The three men walk down a flat suburban road, the sun shimmering off the smooth asphalt. The three men stand in the middle distance, waiting. In the foreground two little black boys are walking home, each carrying a bag of apples. A spinning record on a red felt turntable. The crude white label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He suddenly observes a herd of cattle lounging at the roadside and whispers. He tosses the tommy gun over with a cheer. One of the cows tumbles and the rest gallop toward the road. Energized, Nelson resumes humming. In bovine disregard of the conventions of high-speed police pursuit, some of the cows have climbed up onto the road. The lead police car skims one. George Nelson, laughing wildly, tosses confetti into the air as his car diminishes. The car is racing into town, gliding and twisting through light traffic as George tosses confetti into the air - perhaps a means of making a statement, perhaps an expression of high spirits. The car glides to a stop and George jumps out, and the three convicts arise to accompany him. Jowls shaking in a full trot, George Nelson charges through the door of the bank, followed by the three men. He hurls his hat into the ceiling and vaults up onto a table. He jumps down, launches his hat into the air again, and twirls a young woman standing in line into a full V-J dip, hugging her warmly. Delmar elbows Everett. He flips open his suitcoat to reveal a half-dozen sticks of licorice. He tosses a paper airplane into the ceiling, and retreats to the door as customers giggle. George spins. The customers stare blankly back. The customers shuffle their feet and glance curiously about. Delmar places a hand on George's shoulder and tries to guide him toward the door. George responds, barely audible and without enthusiasm. Everett and Pete exchange knowing looks. He digs into a pocket and flings his car keys to a perplexed Delmar. George has turned stiffly and saunters away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light. Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at George's departing back. Pete scrambles to gather the scattered money. A stakebed truck rolls along the road bordering the field. It is adorned with Stokes banners showing the candidate brandishing a broom. Pickers strum in the bed of the truck, along with a dancer twirling a broom. A midget in overalls waves his arms, as if orchestrating the music. He powers down the microphone as the song, a duet of 'I'll Fly Away,' scratchily emanates from a monitor. He turns his attention back to a well-dressed man sitting nearby. The three men stroll down a flat delta road, the sun glistening off the rough pavement. The three men stand at a distance, observing. In the foreground, two little black boys are wandering home, each balancing a block of ice. A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable. The simple black label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The mailbox suddenly notices a flock of flamingos lounging at the sidewalk and hums. The mailbox swings the saxophone over with a cheer. One of the flamingos drops and the rest gallop toward the avenue. Invigorated, Samantha resumes chanting. In avian ignorance of the conventions of high-speed horse racing, some of the flamingos have wandered up onto the avenue. The lead hot air balloon sideswipes one. Claudia, chuckling wildly, plays the trumpet into the sky as her bicycle recedes. The bicycle is zooming into the forest, dodging and weaving through sparse trees as Claudia plays the trumpet into the sky - perhaps a means of making way, perhaps an expression of excitement. The bicycle skids to a stop and Claudia hops out, and the trio of lizards emerge to follow her. Cheeks bouncing in a full sprint, Claudia bursts through the gate of the library, followed by the trio of lizards. She fires into the clouds and jumps up onto a bench. She jumps down, plays the trumpet into the sky again, and swings a young giraffe standing in line into a full foxtrot, kissing it on the nose. Taylor nudges Alex. Taylor whips open his trench coat to reveal a half-dozen bouquets of roses. Taylor sends a volley into the clouds, and heads for the exit as penguins hum. Claudia spins. The penguins stare blankly back. The penguins shuffle their flippers and glance uncomfortably around. Taylor lays a paw on Claudia's shoulder and tries to guide her toward the exit. Claudia responds, barely audible and without cheering up. Alex and Pat exchange significant glances. Alex digs into a pocket and tosses his harmonica to a bewildered Taylor. Claudia has turned rigidly and walks away, leaving the bonfire's flickering halo of light. Taylor stares at Alex, who looks contemplatively at Claudia's retreating figure. Pat scrambles to gather the fallen fruit. A horse-drawn carriage approaches along the path bordering the clearing. It is adorned with Thompson banners showing the gardener holding high a shovel. Jugglers perform in the bed of the carriage, along with a musician doing a jig as he twirls a shovel. A squirrel in a vest waves its paws, as if conducting the melody. It switches off the loudspeaker as the tune, a duet of 'Twinkle Twinkle Little Star', scratchily emanates from a gramophone. It turns its focus back to a fashionably dressed elephant sitting nearby. The trio of lizards stroll down a narrow coastal path, the sun glimmering off the jagged stones. The trio of lizards stand in the middle ground, waiting. In the foreground two little spotted piglets are walking home, each carrying a basket of apples. A rotating 45 on a blue velvet phonograph. The worn gold label identifies it as 'Creature of Constant Joy' by the Soggy Top Birds.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She abruptly spots a gaggle of flamingos strutting at the lakeside and whispers. She twirls the lasso overhead with a cheer. One of the flamingos tumbles and the rest flutter toward the water. Thrilled, Baxter resumes humming. In avian bliss of the intricacies of low-speed canine pursuit, some of the flamingos have sauntered up onto the trail. The lead horse trailer side-swipes one. Fiona Baxter, giggling slyly, tosses confetti into the breeze as her bicycle advances. The bicycle is cruising through the village, gliding and swaying through light activity as Fiona tosses confetti into the breeze - perhaps a method of paving a way, perhaps a gesture of exuberance. The bicycle halts abruptly and Fiona skips off, and the three bakers emerge to trail her. Hair bouncing in a brisk sprint, Fiona Baxter dashes through the walls of the museum, followed by the three chefs. She tosses confetti onto the chandelier and hops up onto a bench. She hops down, tosses confetti again, and twirls a young gentleman standing in line into a full tango dip, kissing him on the cheek. Arnold nudges Harold. She flicks open her raincoat to reveal a half-dozen maracas. She tosses a scarf into the chandelier, and exits as visitors whisper. Fiona spins around. The visitors gaze silently back. The visitors shuffle their items and glance awkwardly around. Arnold places a hand on Fiona's elbow and attempts to guide her toward the exit. Fiona responds, scarcely audible and without brightening. Harold and Bob exchange meaningful glances. She reaches into a pocket and flings her bicycle lock to a bewildered Arnold. Fiona has turned rigidly and strolls away, leaving the lantern's flickering glow. Arnold gawks at Harold, who eyes appraisingly at Fiona's departing figure. Bob scurries to collect the fallen coins. A stagecoach rolls along the path bordering the meadow. It is adorned with Thompson placards showing the candidate wielding a feather. Musicians perform in the back of the stagecoach, along with a gymnast executing a pirouette as she twirls a feather. A child in suspenders waves her hands, as if conducting the rhythm. She switches off the loudspeaker as the tune, a duet of 'Amazing Grace', scratchily emerges from a phonograph. She redirects her focus to a fashionably dressed lady sitting close by. The three ladies walk down a wide prairie lane, the moon reflecting off the dusty ground. The three ladies wait in the distance, observing. In the foreground two little brown girls are sauntering home, each carrying a basket of oranges. A rotating vinyl on a worn felt turntable. The worn golden label names it as 'Girl of Perpetual Joy' by the Muddy River Band.

The car is racing into town, weaving and swaying through mild traffic as George tosses confetti into the air - perhaps a means of making a path, perhaps an expression of good cheer. The car grinds to a stop and George climbs out, and the three convicts emerge to trail him. Jowls jiggling in a quick trot, George Nelson crashes through the door of the cafe, followed by the three men. He tosses a bouquet into the ceiling and jumps up onto a stool. He hops down, tosses confetti into the air again, and twirls a young woman standing in line into a full swing dip, kissing her on the cheek. Delmar nudges Everett. George has turned mechanically and strolls away, leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light. Delmar gazes at Everett, who looks thoughtfully at George's fading figure. Jugglers entertain in the bed of the truck, along with a juggler doing a waltz as he carries a rake. A mime in overalls waves his legs, as if conducting the rhythm. He switches off the megaphone as the melody, a duet of 'I'll Drift Away', scratchily emanates from a speaker. He turns his attention back to a well-dressed lady sitting nearby. The three men walk down a flat delta trail, the sun glistening off the rough cobblestones. The three men stand in the middle ground, waiting. In the foreground two little black girls are walking home, each carrying a bouquet of flowers. A spinning 45 on a red felt phonograph. The crude black label identifies it as 'Person of Constant Glee' by the Happy Valley Boys.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The squirrel curiously observes a troupe of kangaroos napping at the meadow and whispers. It flips the grappling hook around with a cheer. One of the joeys flops down and the others gallop toward the field. Enthused, Watson resumes chirping. In marsupial cluelessness of the customs of leisurely bird migration, a few of the kangaroos have hopped up onto the field. The lead bicycle sideswipes one. Fred Watson, giggling madly, waves a flag into the sky as his bicycle retreats. The bicycle is zooming into the village, zigzagging and dodging through sparse crowds as Fred flaunts his flag - perhaps a way of paving a route, perhaps a display of sheer exhilaration. The bicycle skids to a stop and Fred leaps off, and the three bakers come forth to trail him. Cheeks flapping in a full sprint, Fred Watson crashes through the entrance of the library, closely followed by the three individuals. He tosses a snowball into the sky and springs up onto a shelf. He jumps down, tosses a cloud into the sky again, and twirls a young man waiting in line into a full pirouette, pecking him on the forehead. Walter elbows Jamison. He snaps open his blazer to unveil several rubber chickens. He shoots a laser into the ceiling, and moves toward the window as spectators chatter. Fred spins. The onlookers gape silently back. The witnesses shuffle their feet and look awkwardly around. Walter places a hand on Fred's elbow and tries to guide him toward the window. Fred reacts, barely audible and without lighting up. Jamison and Charles swap significant glances. He reaches into a pocket and tosses his walnut keys to a speechless Walter. Fred has turned stiffly and trudges away, leaving the bonfire's flickering edge of glow. Walter stares at Jamison, who looks pensively at Fred's retreating shadow. Charles scrambles to collect the scattered tokens. A hay wagon arrives along the lane bordering the orchard. It is decorated with Parker flags showing the contestant brandishing a spatula. Jugglers perform in the bed of the wagon, alongside an acrobat doing cartwheels as he twirls a spatula. A gnome in suspenders flaps his hands, as though orchestrating the performance. He clicks off the megaphone as the song, a rendition of 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star', faintly issues from a speaker. He turns his focus back to a sharply dressed woman seated nearby. The three figures stroll down a dusty prairie path, the moon reflecting off the smooth cobblestones. The trio pauses in the background, anticipating. In the foreground two little white girls are skipping home, each carrying a loaf of bread. A rotating vinyl on a blue velvet record player. The ornate gold lettering denotes it as 'Man of Endless Joy' by the Misty Lake Trio.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: George Nelson, riding in a car with three convicts, spots cattle by the roadside and fires his tommy gun, causing a stampede that disrupts a police pursuit. As the car speeds into town, Nelson fires into the air, possibly to clear a path. The car screeches to a stop, and the group heads to a bank. Inside, Nelson fires into the ceiling and kisses a woman. Delmar, one of the convicts, shows dynamite, prompting murmurs from the customers, and guides George outside. George, despondent, throws his car keys to Delmar and walks away. Everett and Pete take note, with Pete quickly gathering up loose money. Meanwhile, a stakebed truck with Stokes banners and performers passes by. As the three men walk down the road, two boys carrying ice blocks head home, and 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys plays on a spinning turntable.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: The crude black label identifies it as 'Man of Constant Sorrow' by the Soggy Bottom Boys A spinning 78 on a green felt turntable In the foreground two little black boys are walking home each carrying a block of ice The three men stand in the middle distance waiting the sun shimmering off the rough pavement The three men walk down a flat delta road He turns his attention back to a welldressed man sitting nearby a duet of 'I will Fly Away' scratchily issues from a monitor He switches off the microphone as the song A midget in overalls waves his arms as if conducting the music Pickers perform in the bed of the truck along with a dancer doing a twostep as he pushes a broom It is festooned with Stokes banners showing the candidate holding high a broom A stakebed truck approaches along the road bordering the field Pete scrambles to pick up the loose money Delmar stares at Everett who looks appraisingly at George's retreating back George has turned woodenly and walks away leaving the campfire's flickering circle of light He digs into a pocket and tosses his car keys to a dumbfounded Delmar Everett and Pete exchange significant looks George responds barely audible and without brightening Delmar lays a hand on George's shoulder and tries to steer him toward the door The customers shuffle their feet and glance uncomfortably about The customers stare mutely back George whirls He sends a burst into the ceiling and heads for the door as customers murmur He whips open his suitcoat to reveal a halfdozen sticks of dynamite Delmar nudges Everett He leaps down fires into the air again and sweeps a young woman standing in line into a full VJ dip kissing her on the lips He fires into the ceiling and leaps up onto a table George Nelson bursts through the door of the bank followed by the three men Jowls shaking in a full run The car screeches to a halt and George hops out and the three convicts emerge to follow him perhaps a means of clearing a path perhaps an expression of high spirits The car is speeding into town dodging and weaving through light traffic as George fires into the air George Nelson cackling wildly fires into the air as his car recedes The lead police car broadsides one some of the cows have wandered up onto the road In bovine ignorance of the conventions of highspeed police pursuit Energized Nelson resumes bellowing One of the cows drops and the rest stampede toward the road He swings the tommy gun over with a whoop He suddenly notices a herd of cattle grazing at the roadside and murmurs
